definition:
The [*radian*]{} is a of angle used in the higher mathematics. The
magnitude of an angle $\alpha$ is one radian, if the arc corresponding
the angle $\alpha$ as a central angle of a circle is equally long as the
radius of the circle. Thus, a radian is equal to $\frac{180}{\pi}$ ,
minutes and seconds approximately $57^{\mathrm{o}}\,17'\,44.80625''.$

In degrees, a circle has 360 degrees, while in radians a circle has
$2\pi$ radians. In fact, many angles of equilateral polygons are equal
to a multiple of $\pi$ divided by some integer: for example, the
interior angle of an equilateral triangle’s vertex is $\frac{\pi}{3}$,
while the interior angle of an equilateral pentagon’s vertex is
$\frac{3\pi}{5}$.
